awd_titl_txt: A Study of a Technology-enhanced Curriculum Integrating Science, Engineering Design, and Computational Modeling to Achieve Synergistic Learning with Elementary Students
awd_abstract_narration:
As computing has become integral to the practice of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM), the STEM+Computing program seeks to address emerging challenges in computational STEM areas through the applied integration of computational thinking and computing activities within STEM teaching and learning in early childhood education through high school (preK-12).  This project will develop a 6-week unit for upper elementary students that integrates science, engineering, and computational thinking concepts and practices.  The classroom materials to be developed will blend disciplinary core ideas, science and engineering design practices, and crosscutting concepts as described by the Framework for K-12 Science Education and the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS). Expected project outcomes include: (1) A refined, technology-enhanced curriculum unit featuring innovative supportive learning technologies aligned with NGSS performance expectations integrating Earth science, engineering, and computational thinking; (2) A computational systems modeling environment where students can develop models of Earth systems phenomena to test, compare, and refine engineering solutions related to those phenomena; (3) Educative supporting resources that help upper elementary teachers implement the unit and integrate the disciplines of engineering and computational thinking into their science teaching; (4) Empirical evidence of the unit's effectiveness at promoting student proficiency with integrating science, engineering, and computational thinking; and (5) A principled design process for developing NGSS-aligned multidisciplinary curriculum materials.

This design and development project will use a principled design process based on established design approaches--Evidence Centered Design, Knowledge Integration, and Informed Engineering--to ensure that all materials are aligned to the learning goals of the project. The project team will collaborate with schools serving populations of culturally, economically, and linguistically diverse students, and the design process will incorporate a fairness/equity design framework, helping to ensure that assessments, curriculum materials, and technology supports are relevant, fair, and helpful to diverse student groups.  A mixed-methods design-based research approach will be used by the project to investigate the following research questions: (1) How can a technology-enhanced curriculum unit that integrates science, engineering design, and computational modeling help upper elementary students achieve synergistic learning of these disciplines along the three dimensions of the NGSS? (2) What domain-specific supports do upper elementary students need to develop computational models of Earth systems and use computational models to develop engineering solutions? (3) How can supporting resources educate elementary teachers and support their implementation of science curriculum materials integrating engineering and computational thinking? The project will conduct two types of empirical classroom studies to pursue answers to these research questions: (1) A series  of design-based research studies will be conducted during year 2 of the project to address the first two research questions; and (2) A learning and implementation study will be conducted to address all three of the research questions.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

por.por_cntn:
The SPICE project has resulted in (1) a tested and refined NGSS-aligned technology-enhanced 3-week curriculum unit for 5th and 6th grade students that integrates learning in science, engineering, and computational thinking (CT); (2) a suite of teacher resources to help implement this unit; and (3) a validated assessment to measure student learning across the three disciplines. All SPICE curriculum materials and publications are available at https://spiceprojects.org/

Students working on this curriculum solve a water runoff challenge by learning the underlying science concepts related to water runoff, creating their own computational models (CMs) for runoff, and using their CMs to test, refine, and optimize their design solutions to the runoff challenge. Our studies demonstrate that, given appropriate supports, students as early as fifth grade with no prior programming experience can use block-based programming tools to create their own CMs and demonstrate significant learning in science , engineering and CT. Our studies also demonstrate that elementary teachers with little programming experience are able to implement SPICE in their classrooms and provide crucial support for students to engage in science, engineering, and computational practices. 

Our design approach has given rise to a curriculum design framework for integrating engineering, science, and CT using computational modeling (see Framework figure). The overall investigation is framed around an engineering design challenge. This engineering challenge is defined so that its solution is governed by an underlying science phenomenon aligned with unit learning goals. This science phenomenon must, in turn, be modeled computationally in a way that can support students in achieving the engineering solution. After students define the engineering problem, they investigate the underlying science phenomenon and develop a conceptual model that predicts the system behavior. The conceptual model informs students? subsequent development of a CM whose code is incorporated into a simulation that supports design, testing, and refinement of the engineering solution.

This framework, and in turn the SPICE curriculum, offers upper elementary students and teachers a rare opportunity to engage in simulation-based engineering designing and testing instead of hands-on physical engineering building and testing to explore tangible mechanisms. In more typical elementary school engineering tasks, because of the time it takes to build physical prototypes, students are generally limited in their exploration of the solution space. This shifts the focus to the nuances of building rather than the design-test-refine engineering process. This can cause young students to develop a limited view of how engineers generate and compare multiple possible design solutions.  In contrast, the SPICE curriculum  allows for a more comprehensive exploration of the solution space and comparison of a wider variety of possible design solutions, while emphasizing that computational tools are an important part of an engineer?s toolbox.

Implementing our curriculum design framework has resulted in three design perspectives for integrating the three disciplines, namely (1) creating an explicit need for computational modeling, (2) maintaining coherence across system representations across disciplines, and (3) employing a domain specific modeling language (DSML). To support fifth and sixth grade students in developing water runoff CMs, the SPICE project team developed an Earth Science DSML that supported the translation of students? science knowledge into a computational form, especially for students with limited computing and math background. To engage students in age-appropriate CT concepts and practices, we greatly simplified the desired CM to match the math proficiencies of typical fifth and sixth grade students. Therefore, the designed DSML abstracts the concept of rate (e.g., inches/hour for the intensity of rainfall and the concept of absorption rate) and the idea of a step-by-step simulation model, where students compute values of parameters that change with time in 𝜟t time steps. Instead, students simply state the total rainfall in inches. Similarly, the absorption of a material is expressed by an absorption limit for the surface material. Moreover, these modeling constructs (e.g., absorption limit for the surface material) are directly linked to the terminology used in the science and engineering lessons. 

Based on our empirical studies and iterative curriculum design refinements, we have also synthesized a set of six design guidelines for promoting CT in integrated STEM+CT instruction. Guidelines for preparing students for CM development include (1) Support conceptual modeling of science phenomena prior to CM development and (2) Introduce CT concepts required for developing CMs using a familiar context. Guidelines for supporting the CM development process include (1) Engage a limited and age-appropriate set of CT concepts and practices and (2) Support model decomposition. Guidelines for supporting CM evaluation include (1) Support CM testing and the selection of test cases and (2) Include opportunities for students to engage with debugging. 

 


Last Modified: 12/26/2022
Modified by: Satabdi Basu
